title: Understanding Hospital Care
description: Navigate hospital visits confidently, from emergency room to discharge, understanding who cares for you and your rights as a patient.

content.overview: The emergency room (ER) provides care for serious and life-threatening conditions. Understanding how it works helps you know what to expect.

emergency_symptoms: Signs of stroke (face drooping, arm weakness, speech difficulty)
Severe bleeding that will not stop
Suicidal thoughts or severe mental health crisis

what_happens_in_er.description: Give your information, insurance, and briefly describe why you are there
A nurse assesses how urgent your condition is and assigns a priority level
You may wait to be seen - sickest patients are seen first, not first come first served
You are taken to a treatment room or bed when space is available
Doctor or nurse practitioner examines you and orders tests if needed
Blood work, imaging, medications, or procedures as needed
Decision is made to send you home, admit to hospital, or transfer

triage_explained.what_it_is: A system to prioritize patients based on how sick they are
categories: Urgent - seen after more critical patients
triage_explained.important_to_know: Your wait time depends on your condition compared to others, not when you arrived

what_to_bring: Comfort items for potential long wait
tips: Tell the nurse if your symptoms change or worsen while waiting
Ask questions about what is happening and why
You can have a family member or friend with you
Know that ER care is expensive - understand your insurance coverage

content.overview: If you need to stay in the hospital, understanding the admission process helps you know what to expect.

types_of_admission.description: Admitted through the ER for urgent conditions
types_of_admission.how_it_happens: ER doctor determines you need to stay for treatment

types_of_admission.description: Planned hospital stay, often for surgery
Your doctor sends you directly to the hospital
types_of_admission.how_it_happens: Doctor calls ahead to arrange your bed

inpatient_status.medicare_note: Medicare Part A covers inpatient stays

observation_status.definition: In a hospital bed but technically outpatient
observation_status.insurance_coverage: Covered under outpatient benefits - may cost more
observation_status.medicare_note: Covered under Part B with different cost-sharing
observation_status.important: You may not know which status you are in - always ask

important_distinction.your_right: You have the right to know your status and can request a Medicare Outpatient Observation Notice (MOON) if applicable

admission_process_steps.title: Registration
admission_process_steps.what_happens: Provide personal info, insurance, emergency contacts, advance directives

admission_process_steps.title: Medical evaluation
admission_process_steps.what_happens: Admission history and physical by doctor or nurse practitioner

admission_process_steps.title: Room assignment
admission_process_steps.what_happens: Assigned to appropriate unit based on your condition

admission_process_steps.title: Nursing intake
admission_process_steps.what_happens: Nurses assess you and create care plan

admission_process_steps.title: Medication reconciliation
admission_process_steps.what_happens: Review all medications you take at home

what_to_bring_for_hospital_stay: Advance directives if you have them
List of doctors and their contact information
Comfortable clothing and slippers with non-slip soles
CPAP machine if you use one
content.valuables_warning: Leave jewelry and valuables at home - hospitals are not responsible for lost items

sections.title: Who Is Who in the Hospital

content.overview: Many different people will care for you in the hospital. Understanding their roles helps you know who to ask for what.

medical_team.description: The doctor ultimately responsible for your care
medical_team.recognizable_by: Usually wears white coat; should introduce themselves as your doctor
medical_team.ask_them_about: Major decisions about your care and treatment plan

medical_team.description: A doctor who specializes in hospital care
medical_team.recognizable_by: May be your attending if your regular doctor does not work in the hospital
medical_team.ask_them_about: Daily updates on your condition and plan

medical_team.description: A doctor in training (has completed medical school)
medical_team.recognizable_by: Often seen in teaching hospitals; usually younger
medical_team.ask_them_about: Routine questions; they report to the attending

medical_team.description: A student training to become a doctor
medical_team.recognizable_by: Usually in teaching hospitals; may ask to examine you
medical_team.your_rights: You can decline to have students involved in your care

medical_team.description: Doctors with expertise in specific areas called in for your care
medical_team.ask_them_about: Their specific area of expertise related to your condition

nursing_team.ask_them_about: Almost anything - they know your care plan best

nursing_team.description: Advanced practice providers who can diagnose, order tests, and prescribe
nursing_team.responsibilities: Similar to physicians in many ways

nursing_team.description: Helps with daily activities and basic care
nursing_team.ask_them_about: Help with daily needs and comfort

other_team_members.ask_them_about: Questions about your medications, side effects, interactions

other_team_members.description: Helps you regain strength and mobility

other_team_members.ask_them_about: Dressing, bathing, cooking, returning to normal life
Insurance, discharge planning, community resources, emotional support
What happens next, where you will go after hospital
Spiritual needs, religious practices, emotional support

other_team_members.description: Helps resolve concerns about your care
other_team_members.ask_them_about: Problems with your care, questions about your rights

tips_for_communication: Ask everyone to introduce themselves and their role
Write down names and roles of key team members
Do not hesitate to ask for the nurse if you need help
Request to speak to the attending physician for important decisions
Ask for contact numbers for after discharge

content.overview: As a hospital patient, you have specific rights protected by law and hospital policy. Knowing your rights helps you participate actively in your care.

fundamental_rights.means: Care that respects your dignity, values, and beliefs regardless of your background
Clear explanations of your diagnosis, treatment options, and who is providing care
Be involved in all decisions about your care and treatment
Say no to any treatment or procedure (with some exceptions for emergencies or court orders)
Understand and agree to treatments before they happen
Your medical information is confidential; discussions held privately
Receive care in a safe environment free from abuse and neglect
Voice concerns without fear of retaliation

visitors: You can have visitors of your choosing
You can designate who may visit
Same-sex partners and non-family have visitation rights
communication: Receive information in a language you understand
advance_directives: Right to create or change advance directives
Cannot be required to have one to receive care
billing: Know the charges before procedures when possible

if_you_have_concerns: Speak with your nurse or doctor first
Ask to speak with the charge nurse or supervisor
Contact the patient advocate or patient relations
File a formal complaint if needed
if_rights_are_violated: File complaint with The Joint Commission
Seek legal advice for serious violations

hipaa_in_the_hospital.your_information_protected: Medical staff cannot share your information without permission
hipaa_in_the_hospital.exceptions: Some information may be shared with family unless you object
your_controls: You can request to opt out of hospital directory
You can specify who can receive your information

patient_responsibilities: Ask questions when you do not understand

content.overview: Leaving the hospital safely requires planning. Good discharge planning helps you recover and prevents returning to the hospital.

discharge_planning_starts_early.your_role: Participate actively in planning - share concerns and preferences

where_you_might_go.when_appropriate: You can manage independently with outpatient follow-up
You need some professional help but not 24-hour care
where_you_might_go.services: Nursing visits, therapy, wound care at home

where_you_might_go.when_appropriate: You need 24-hour nursing care and rehabilitation
where_you_might_go.medicare_coverage: May be covered after 3-day hospital stay (inpatient status)

where_you_might_go.when_appropriate: Complex medical needs requiring extended hospital-level care
Focus on comfort for terminal illness
where_you_might_go.setting: Can be at home, in hospice facility, or nursing home

discharge_process.your_action: Ask about timing and any pending results
Read carefully, ask questions about anything unclear
Understand which medications to take, which to stop, new ones
Confirm dates and times, note any transportation needs
Fill before leaving if hospital pharmacy available, or same day
Make sure you understand warning signs and when to seek help
Have a safe way to get home

what_to_do: Make sure a family member also understands
Keep in a safe place at home

preventing_readmission: Know warning signs that mean you should seek help
Ask about home health services if needed
Make sure you have help at home if needed
Fill prescriptions before you need them

you_have_right_to: Participate in decisions about where you go
Appeal discharge if you think it is too soon (Medicare patients)
your_rights_at_discharge.important_medicare_rule: Medicare patients must receive Important Message from Medicare notice and can request Quality Improvement Organization (QIO) review if they believe discharge is premature

content.overview: Hospitals can be dangerous places due to infections, medication errors, and other risks. Being an active participant helps keep you safe.

your_role: Ask everyone to wash hands before touching you
Ask if catheters and IVs are still necessary
Keep wounds clean and report any changes
what_hospital_should_do: Remove catheters when no longer needed

your_role: Know all medications you take at home
Ask about every medication given to you in hospital
Verify medication name, dose, and timing
Report any allergies or previous reactions
Speak up if something seems wrong
questions_to_ask: Is this the medication my doctor ordered?
What are the possible side effects?
Does this replace any of my home medications?

your_role: Call for help before getting out of bed
Make sure path to bathroom is clear

when_to_speak_up: You have not heard from your doctor
You do not understand what is happening
how_to_speak_up: Use I statements: I am concerned that...
Ask questions: Can you explain why...?
Ask to speak with supervisor if concerns not addressed

rapid_response.what_it_is: A team that can be called for patients getting worse
rapid_response.when_to_call: If you or family notice sudden decline that is not being addressed
rapid_response.how_to_call: Ask staff or call switchboard; family can often activate

preventing_pressure_injuries.what_they_are: Skin breakdown from staying in one position
prevention: Report any skin pain or redness
Stay as active as safely possible
Move legs and ankles while in bed
Get up and walk when allowed

content.overview: Understanding what happens before, during, and after surgery helps you prepare and participate in safe care.

preoperative_appointment.purpose: Evaluate your health and prepare for surgery

preparing_at_home: Follow instructions about eating and drinking before surgery
Take or stop medications as instructed
Arrange transportation and help at home
Pack bag for hospital stay if staying overnight

check_in_process: Receive IV for fluids and medications
surgical_safety_checks: Verification of identity (expect to confirm name and birthdate multiple times)
Marking of surgical site (you should see this happen)
Time-out before surgery (entire team verifies correct patient, procedure, site)

anesthesia_options.description: Relaxed and drowsy but not fully asleep

managing_pain: Use non-medication methods too (ice, positioning, distraction)
Understand plan for weaning off strong pain medications
preventing_complications: Cough and deep breathe as instructed
Get up and move as soon as allowed
Watch for warning signs of complications
warning_signs: Redness, swelling, or drainage from incision

questions_to_ask_surgeon: How many times have you performed this surgery?
What are the most common complications?
What is the expected recovery time?
When can I return to normal activities?
What happens if something goes wrong?
Who covers for you if I have problems after surgery?

key_vocabulary.definition: A system for prioritizing patients based on the severity of their condition
A patient formally admitted to the hospital
In a hospital bed but classified as outpatient, affecting insurance coverage
The doctor ultimately responsible for your care in the hospital
The process of preparing for you to leave the hospital safely
Your agreement to treatment after understanding the risks, benefits, and alternatives
A team that can be called when a patient is getting worse and needs immediate attention

action_items.action: Know when to go to the ER versus urgent care
action_items.why: Get appropriate care and avoid unnecessary ER costs

action_items.action: Ask about your admission status (inpatient vs observation)
action_items.why: Affects your insurance coverage and costs
Ensures you have what you need to recover at home

action_items.action: Ask everyone who enters your room to wash their hands
Know the warning signs to watch for after discharge
action_items.why: Catch problems early and prevent readmission
